1. It seems that `heron` will make using `.heronrc` mandatory? Does it fallback to current parser? Please provide tests for the case that `.heronrc` cannot be found or be parsed correctly.

@kramasamy How would we like to do the initial meeting? I imagine a video group chat would be really hard given everyone's schedule.

Would listing tasks in bullet points here be more achievable? Haven't jumped in yet, btw.

I plan to work on this in the coming weeks, not quite to the stream processing part of my project yet, but when I get there, I'll likely build a Kubernetes integration for Heron if nobody else has yet.

With Kubernetes you have a few tools that could make Heron work nicely. It seems you have pluggable schedulers in Heron which is ideal for Kubernetes, really all you'll need to do is write some code to interface with the Kubernetes API. In every Kubernetes container on default you get a file with a token used to authenticate against the API at 10.0.0.1. From there it's fairly easy to implement your own scheduler logic for pods.

Is it necessary to list the files in tar file? Similarly, if `-s` is not provided to `curl`, `curl` will show progress bar. Is progress bar necessary?

Hi @objmagic,

@kramasamy debugged this issue ( thanks! ). Below is a explanation in his words. We had this discussion on slack

```
previous to the refactor
heron-executor depended only pyyam

https://github.com/twitter/heron/commit/a9d4861813eb27a692dce7bfdeb8d3ad75fc0059
heron executor refactor and unit tests (#1134) ¬∑ twitter/heron@a9d4861 ¬∑ GitHub
* switch order of monitor process * committing the unit tests * committing the unit tests * fix unit tests * updating comments * change most methods to be private * One last c... 

according to BUILD file
with the refactor it also includes - statemanager etc
that pulls in zookeeper changes
now when heron-executor itself is run - it needs a pex directory to explode itself
in this case it uses ~/.pex
when heron executor executes process like heron-shell etc
they use the container .pex directory
and hence you have two .pex directories
```

#1140 fixed the heron-shell issue. This one fixes the new error after the refactor commit.

Some notes on this:
- We have two projects, [pystorm](https://github.com/pystorm/pystorm) and [streamparse](https://github.com/Parsely/streamparse). The former is an implementation of basic APIs for bolts/spouts and implementation based on Storm's multi-lang protocol. The latter is the actual framework for managing "projects" with multiple topologies that are written using the `pystorm` API.
- As of our very-recent 3.0.0+ release, topologies themselves are specified using a Python Topology DSL, based on thriftpy to serialize the topology into a Thrift Topology struct. We serialize that by embedding a copy of `storm.thrift` inside `streamparse`, as shown [in this code](https://github.com/Parsely/streamparse/blob/master/streamparse/thrift.py).
- You can read some docs on [the way the Topology DSL works here](http://streamparse.readthedocs.io/en/stable/topologies.html#topology-dsl).

Hey! One of the streamparse original creators here. This is looking really interesting so far! I added a comment on #574 about recent happenings in pystorm & streamparse. But I agree with the approach you've taken of building your own pyheron interop layer and then just matching the duck-typed API that streamparse's Topology DSL and that pystorm components implement.
@daxwang - thanks for the use case, definitely interesting. Will discuss this with our team and keep you posted.
Thanks! Please resolve the conflict and we can merge this.

I'm not sure how action listener in Bazel works in detail, but when you build project, bazel will say, for example, "46 files found by checkstyle" (when building target xxx). We can then use multiple processes to check style to accelerate. 

As for the bug reporting, Pylint usually dumps out information which clearly indicates which module has bad style. Parallelism will not create much hassle here.

related to #1146 

@joestein do you still want to work on this?
This issue is quite annoying, but good news is that people on Bazel mailing list suggests [Bazel 0.3.1](https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/releases/tag/0.3.1) may have fixed this.
would the current contents of README.md under heron/cli/src/python/ suffice for documentation?
do you mean put them as comment/documentation in the source code, or add a way to display them when user enters `help` subcommand?

@prabhuinbarajan and @objmagic - current README is fine. But we need some detailed documentation to be put in the web page. Can you open an issue to track this? We can do the entire documentation in a separate PR.

For java we found the "N files found for checkstyle" output was misleading when inferring where build time was spent. It turned out that the checkstyle was in fact very fast compared to the compile, but since the checkstyle output log info it appeared (as a red herring) to be the time sink. Before adding parallelism I'd want to see some timing numbers showing how much savings we'd achieve. My suspicion is not much.

(Personally, I'd rather see the file that produces the style errors upon a failure, which is currently difficult to determine)
@kramasamy thinks for milestone 0.14.3, we should upgrade to Protobuf 3.0.0 and use C++ implementation underhood for Python protobuf. Investigating flatbuffer may take much longer time. cc @maosongfu

@billonahill @kramasamy I just used `time` to get the difference. It turns out you are right --- the difference is negligible. Let's close this PR.

https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/804

to get the Kafka spout in. We are bumping this a priority for the next release - 0.14.3.

On Thursday, August 4, 2016, Taishi Nojima notifications@github.com wrote:

> Heron Executor currently uses its own print function do_print()
> https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/executor/src/python/heron_executor.py#L41,
> instead of heron's common logging module (heron/common/src/python/
> utils/log.py). In order to make logging uniform, it's better for the
> executor to use this as well, but there are several potential issues:
> 1. Since stdout/stderr of the executor is already redirected to a file
>    (heron-executor.stdout) by the scheduler, any logs from the executor should
>    be output to stdout. That case, we can't use the existing StreamHandler
>    https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/common/src/python/utils/log.py#L56,
>    because ugly escape characters from colorlog will also be in the log file.
>    A possible solution is to create another StreamHandler that doesn't use
>    colorlog.
> 2. Heron Executor does not use any other common modules (under
>    heron/common/src/python), meaning that importing the whole heron's
>    python common library just for log.py is quite cumbersome (since it
>    includes unnecessary dependencies, like tornado, as well). One possible
>    solution is to create another BUILD rule, such as one just for logging.
> 
> What would be the best solution?
> 
> ‚Äî

I agree with Bill. It's a good idea to introduce more granularity at this stage. By the way, you can make a dependency graph on your [tnojima/python_topo](https://github.com/taishi8117/heron/commits/tnojima/python_topo) branch by:

``` Bash
$ bazel query 'deps(heron/common/src/python:common)' --output graph > heron-py-common.dot
$ dot -Tpng heron-py-common.dot > heron-py-common.png
```

![heron-py-common](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3656079/17444884/31a80212-5af7-11e6-90b4-a6290e24bcb5.png)

As we can see, we could introduce tons of unnecessary Protobuf dependencies even if we just want to use `log`.

Besides introducing more granularity (adding `BUILD` file per subdirectory), I think we should also be careful on when to include dependency `//heron/proto:proto-py`. Please identify precisely the **subdirectories** that require Protobuf. Do not add Protobuf dependency on toplevel BUILD file under `heron/common/src/python`.

@billonahill methods like `c.t.h.spi.packing.PackingPlan.getInstanceDistribution()` seem to be serializing packing plan into strings. Will this change make such custom methods redundant and removable?

@ashvina good observation. I'd love to remove then and that was my initial intent, but the executor needs that info and is written in python. Serializing it means we don't need to change the executor code, so I kept in there for now. Without it we'd need to reimplement that logic in python to reconstruct. I don't love having the logic implemented in two places, but I agree we might want to do that instead before we ship scaling, but in a later patch.
